Award.AwardTitle: Photodetectors for the SuperNEMO Demonstrator Module
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neutrino oscillations not only demonstrate that neutrinos have mass but also imply the existence of new symmetries beyond the Standard Model. These new observations strongly motivate further studies of the intrinsic properties of neutrinos, including tests of whether they are Majorana or Dirac-type particles. Natural conjectures suggest that a deeper understanding of neutrinos may provide a glimpse onto phenomena at a Planck-scale energy level, could broaden our knowledge of the fundamental forces, could shed light onto the initial creation of leptons and baryons, and can help to improve our understanding of the early evolution of the Universe. Majorana-type neutrinos lead to a neutrinoless double beta decay (NDBD) − the second-order weak nuclear process for which an initial state nucleus with atomic weight and number (A, Z) is transformed into a nucleus of (A, Z + 2), with the emission of only two electrons. In this transition, the lepton number changes by two units and the two electrons in the final state carry the energy equal to the energy of nuclear transition. This award will provide funds to purchase 200 8-inch diameter PMTs to complete the construction of the first SuperNEMO module, the Demonstrator. The next three years are critical so this contribution is timely and crucial to the success of this phase of the experiment.

Among the broader impacts of this project, unraveling the nature of neutrinos will have far-reaching implications for better understanding of elementary particles and their fundamental interactions. On the technical side, the group is developing a unique low background counting technique which may be applied outside of physics and can be of general benefit to society. They educate and train young researchers in building state-of-the-art science projects. They propose to build an exhibit gallery on the UT campus illustrating the discovery, the underlying physics, and applications of natural radioactivity, cosmic rays, and related subatomic phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our particle physics group at the University of Texas at Austin is involved in a subatomic physics experiment called SuperNEMO whose objective is to search for hypothetical nuclear transitions - neutrino-less double beta decays. If observed, such decays would signify that neutrinos and their antiparticles, antineutrinos, could represent the same fundamental quantum field of matter.  This would be a unique property among all elementary particles, a property that has far reaching consequences not only for our better understanding of neutrinos - the most copious matter particles in Universe, but could lead to the explanation of the observed matter-antimatter asymmetry of the Universe and its evolution since the Big Bang.

SuperNEMO is an international project that involves researchers and engineers from France, the UK, Russia, Japan, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Finland, and the US.  The two US groups, at the University of Texas at Austin and at the Idaho National Laboratory, provide major intellectual and technical contributions and are among key players of this endeavor. Components of the experiment are fabricated at many participating institutions and assembled in an underground laboratory. The laboratory is located in a cavern, deep under the Alps and connected to the Frejus road tunnel near Modane in France. This is one of the best locations for such experiments in the world, providing superb shielding from cosmic rays due to a massive mountain overburden, and the laboratory has an easy access through the horizontal commercial tunnel.

SuperNEMO will be built in stages. Currently, the collaboration is assembling a first module that is to demonstrate that some specific design parameters, primarily related to the high radio-purity of materials and effective shielding against natural radioactivity, have been achieved. This is in addition to many other technical aspects of the unique technique for searching for neutrino-less double beta decays that SuperNEMO employs. The technique, unlike in most other such experiments, allows full reconstruction and measurement of kinematical and topological properties of the two electrons observed in the final state of double beta decays. 

The key parts of the detector are: 1) thin foils made out of enriched selenium-82 isotope - the source of double beta decays, 2) wire drift chambers for reconstructing electron trajectories, 3) scintillator blocks with photodetectors for energy and time measurements of decay products. These key parts are shielded from the local natural radioactivity in the cavern. The US groups are collaborating primarily on the foils and the energy-measuring systems.

The scintillator blocks produce light as a result of electrons striking the block. The higher the energy of electrons, the more light is generated. This light is detected ("seen") by photodetectors ("the eyes of the experiment") and converted to an electric pulse. The higher the electron energy, the bigger the electric pulse. SuperNEMO's photodetectors are vacuum photo-multiplier tubes that can cover the large area of the scintillator so they collect a relatively large fraction of the scintillation light, thus enabling the energy measurement with good resolution. This calorimetric measurement is common in particle physics detectors, but the energy resolution achieved by SuperNEMO is one of the best for such a configuration.

The award allowed our group to supply a majority of "the eyes of SuperNEMO" - the 8-inch diameter photomultiplier tubes. They are fabricated by the world's largest and best manufacturer of these devices - Hamamatsu Photonics K. K. in Japan. The grant has been critical for carrying the detector construction forward and constitutes a major contribution to this international project.
